items.content_html:
Description

The name of the event has changed to ContentVisibilityAutoStateChangeEvent.

Motivation

To keep up with the change in standards and browsers.

Additional details

In w3c/csswg-drafts#7603 (comment) the CSSWG resolved to change the name of the event to use present tense.

The spec change hasn't landed yet (I'm working on it at w3c/csswg-drafts#8413 ), but both Mozilla and Chromium have already updated their implementation to use the new name.

https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/6095dabf5574
https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/9851571ecb54c47a205b2321006577b9799c0ea3

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update `ContentVisibilityAutoStateChangedEvent` to `ContentVisibilityAutoStateChangeEvent`
CSS Module landing page: filter effects

items.content_html:
This PR is to support mdn/yari#8132, which makes the Learn sidebar code a lot simpler by deriving link text in the sidebar from page titles, rather than maintaining the link text separately in a huge string map in the macro.

However, one side effect of this is that the links in the sidebar need to be to pages, not page fragments. At the moment this is not the case for the "Common questions" bit of Learn: https://github.com/mdn/yari/blob/92c7a279ee2b9256a37574c32a0cb9c0c8e6a8b5/kumascript/macros/LearnSidebar.ejs#L2597-L2599 - in three cases - "Web mechanics", "Tools and setup", and "Design and accessibility" - the sidebar links to a fragment inside the "Common questions" page.

So this PR creates standalone pages for those three categories. That's in this commit: c318bde .

I've also moved the individual articles inside their category, so for example https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Common_questions/Upload_files_to_a_web_server gets moved under https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Common_questions/Tools_and_setup/Upload_files_to_a_web_server. That's in this commit: d5c72aa. This part is not really necessary for this all to work but it seemed much neater that way. It does make this PR look very big but that is mostly because some of these pages have lots of images, which got moved along with the index.md file.

I think this PR is only worth doing if we do want to go ahead with mdn/yari#8132. I think we should though, unless there's a problem with that PR that I've not thought of.
items.title: Learn area: put "common questions" sections in separate pages

items.title: fix grammatical issues in mobile accessibility

items.content_html:
Description

Updating the outdated documents that deal with Storage Access API/ storage access grants. Storage is always partitioned and storage access grants are limited to access to cookies now.

Motivation

The documentation about the Storage Access API and automatic storage access grants are outdated since the implementation changed in Fx109. The outdated documentation led to confusion because developers expected to see the old behavior.

Additional details

Release notes: https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/109.0/releasenotes/
Meta bug: Bug 1758737 - [meta] Always Partition Storage

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: WIP: Updating content that storage is always partitioned

items.content_html:
Description

Documents the composition of the content script global.

Motivation

Content scripts in extensions behave somewhat consistently across browsers, except when they don't. This is currently not clearly documented, and occasionally confuses extension developers.

Additional details

Related bugs:

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1208775 (and linked bugs)
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1288284

Examples of bugs showing confusion from extension developers:

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1577400
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1681809
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1814898

Related issues and pull requests

None
items.title: Document composition of content script global

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds documentation for the WebGPU API (or, at least some of it, we might have to break it up into multiple PRs as it is quite big). This is expected to land in Chrome 114 or so (around April-ish).

Other notes:

  • There is currently no WebGPU spec or compat data written for MDN. This will be added to https://github.com/mdn/browser-compat-data soon, so don't worry about the related errors showing up.
  • A lot of the red broken links are currently down to the fact that many of the API reference pages are not yet written. These will become fewer in time.
  • The basic examples I wrote to go along with these docs are currently stored on glitch, but I'll put them on an MDN demo repo before the final publication.

You can see full details of the changes expected in this PR in my research document.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #23336
items.title: WebGPU API docs
